I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The project will support environmentally sustainable and socially inclusive development in 
the cities of Ha Giang, Hue, and Vinh Yen in Viet Nam to enhance their economic competitiveness. 
It will (i) control urban stormwater runoff and reduce flood risks, (ii) improve sanitation for public 
health, (iii) enhance green landscaping and public amenities, (iv) upgrade urban road networks 
and  their  connectivity,  and  (v)  promote  public  participation  in  planning.  The  project  will 
demonstrate green and climate-resilient development approaches that will be scaled up for 
nationwide secondary green city development in Viet Nam. This technical assistance (TA) will 
provide much needed capacity development support. 
 
2.  Development constraints. Because of rapid urbanization, 31.1 million people live in cities 
in Viet Nam, and they contributed about 70% of the country’s gross domestic product in 2015 
($193.4 billion).1 Although a structural shift from agriculture to industry and services is driving Viet 
Nam’s rapid growth, the country’s urbanization is uneven because development of secondary 
cities is lagging.2 In secondary cities, only 10% of their urban wastewater is treated by a 
centralized system, and domestic wastewater treatment relies heavily on poorly maintained 
household septic tanks. The lack of proper stormwater management has reduced the capacity of 
drainage systems and causes frequent flooding. Many urban road networks reach their capacity 
and have difficulty accommodating an increasing number of vehicles. Moreover, climate change 
can severely impact secondary cities regardless of their location. By 2100, a projected sea-level 
rise of 100 centimeters could flood a 40,000-square-kilometer area and affect an estimated 9 
million–11 million people.3. 
 
3.  Government effort and challenges. Viet Nam’s Socio-Economic Development Strategy, 
2011–2020 aims to sustain economic growth rates while achieving social inclusiveness and 
environmental protection.4 This has led the government to issue the National Program on Urban 
Development,  and  to  guide  efficient,  sustainable,  and  equitable  urbanization. 5  However, 
secondary cities are constrained by the lack of financial resources and local investment because 
of insufficient basic urban infrastructure and services.6 Infrastructure development in these cities 
relies heavily on public investment as their limited size and coverage cannot support economies 
of scale or cost recovery. Yet, their weak capacity to plan, design, and prioritize investments 
prevents the efficient use of public funds and application of innovative ideas. Secondary cities’ 
slow development prevents them from contributing to the national socioeconomic growth, through 
(i) providing job opportunities and livable environments for locals and migrant workers; and (ii) 
minimizing income disparities by supporting the growth of middle-income groups 
 
4.  The government requested assistance from the Asian Development Bank (ADB), which 
has been supporting the comprehensive basic urban infrastructure development in secondary

constraints requires strategic support in upstream city planning, and the identification of prioritized 
and effective investments for cities. ADB selected Ha Giang, Hue, and Vinh Yen as demonstration 
cities because they represent different socioeconomic characteristics, development constraints 
and priorities, and geographic locations; and supported the preparation of a GrEEEn city action 
plan (GCAP) for each city.8 The GCAPs mainstreamed integrated urban planning and the 
preparation of an investment framework to boost the cities’ economic competitiveness while 
incorporating  climate  resilience,  social  inclusiveness,  and  environmental  sustainability  in 
infrastructure planning and development. 
 
5.  ADB’s  value  addition.  ADB’s  proposed  solution  builds  on  knowledge  work  and 
addresses complex secondary city development issues through TA and loan projects. The project 
components were selected based on ADB’s capacity development TA9 that conceptualized, 
analyzed, and integrated green and climate-resilient development approaches in cities. Project 
preparatory TA10 refined the GCAPs and prioritized investment for city development. The project 
impact  will  be  the  improved  efficiency,  sustainability,  and  equitability  of  secondary  cities 
development in Viet Nam. The project outcome will be strengthened environmental sustainability, 
inclusiveness, and climate resilience of Ha Giang, Hue, and Vinh Yen. The project is estimated 
to cost $223.9 million. The government has requested (i) a regular loan of $50 million and (ii) 
concessional loan of $120 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance the project. 
The Global Environment Facility (GEF) will provide grant cofinancing equivalent to $2.0 million 
and the UCCRTF under the UFPF will provide grant cofinancing equivalent to $4.0 million, both 
to be administered by ADB, pursuant to terms and conditions set forth in the grant agreements. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
6.  The challenge of mainstreaming the green city development approach in Viet Nam stems 
from (i) the slow uptake of the national-level policy framework to build an enabling environment 
to promote green city development, (ii) limited human and financial capacity at the provincial and 
city levels to build an adequate pool of successful models, and (iii) insufficient analysis of 
innovative approaches for green and climate-resilient development in the project cities. The 
proposed TA will help refine, scale up, and strengthen foundations for promoting green city 
development in Viet Nam. It will build on ADB’s past and ongoing knowledge and financial support. 
The TA attached to the project will leverage the project impact by (i) updating and refining the 
GCAPs and improving overall city master plans for Ha Giang, Hue, and Vinh Yen; (ii) replicating 
the approach to secondary city development elsewhere in Viet Nam; and (iii) mainstreaming 
integrated green and climate-resilient development through national policy and regulatory reform. 
The TA will be managed by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE), the 
key central agency to coordinate and promote national climate resilience in Viet Nam.11

B.  Outputs and Activities  
7.  Output 1: Formulated national regulatory framework for an enabling environment 
for sustainable and resilient cities. This output will enhance the enabling environment of 
national policies and guidelines to promote green city, and standardize methods for environmental 
planning in Viet Nam. The MONRE is preparing a directive that will be used as a platform to 
integrate climate resilience approaches, environmental protection, and investment planning in the 
city  master  plan.  The  output  will  strengthen  institutional  capacity  for  pollution  control  and 
management required for the implementation of Circular No. 31/2016/TT-BTNMT by the MONRE. 
Additional support will: (i) develop standardized methodologies for the city-level greenhouse gas 
(GHG) inventory, and climate vulnerability and ecological assessment12; (ii) recommend a set of 
“green city” indicators suitable for secondary cities and establish a nationwide database; (iii) 
develop harmonized methodologies and guidelines for prioritizing environmentally friendly and 
climate resilience investments and its monitoring and reporting mechanism at the city level; and 
(iv) strengthen MONRE’s general capacity for environmental management that builds on its 
mandates for climate change and land use. The output will include a draft orientation plan for a 
standardized national approach to green and resilient secondary city development in Viet Nam. 
 
8.  Output 2: Demonstrated sustainable and resilient development in Ha Giang, Hue, 
and Vinh Yen. This output will provide direct technical support to the project implementing 
agencies and their project management units in Ha Giang, Hue, and Vinh Yen. To progress the 
environmentally sustainable investments, the output will: (i) incorporate environmental and green 
features into project design and procurement; (ii) promote the use of environmentally sustainable 
materials and methods; (iii) assist with monitoring and evaluation with respect to green and low 
carbon development; (iv) strengthen capacities to operate and maintenance the infrastructure 
assets, control environmental pollution, and plan and rehabilitate the affected environment; (v) 
provide resources for climate adaptation monitoring and preparedness equipment; and (vi) 
enhance urban resilience for preparation and response to environmental incidents and disasters. 
 
9.  Output 3: Prepared and tested innovative climate risk financing in Hue. This output 
will explore innovative financial mechanism and strengthen Hue’s disaster risk finance capacity 
by analyzing the relevant legal, financial, institutional frameworks, and formulating a necessary 
asset database for disaster risk finance consideration. This includes (i) providing support to 
formulate and/or identify an appropriate regulatory framework to purchase climate risk insurance; 
(ii)  identifying  applicability  of  indemnity  insurance  and  a  sustainable  premium  payment 
mechanism; (iii) asset mapping and evaluation; (iv) developing an asset management plan; and 
(v) market placement and knowledge sharing. The TA will build upon previous study on finding 
financing solutions to deal with the costs of disasters.13 
   
10.  Output 4: Enhanced and replicated integrated and resilient environmental planning 
at the city and provincial levels. This output will improve Vietnamese cities’ capacity for climate 
change adaptation, strategic environmental assessment, and livability priorities. It will enhance 
the  existing  GCAPs  for  Ha  Giang,  Hue,  and  Vinh  Yen  for  further  integrated  and  resilient 
environmental  planning.  The  updated  GCAPs  will  comprehensively  cover  environmental 
monitoring  and  evaluation frameworks, a  biodiversity  conservation  plan,  a GHG  emissions 
inventory,  low  carbon  development  targets,  a  climate  risk  vulnerability  assessment,  the

prioritization of environmental and resilience projects, and financing plans. The consultation 
process will ensure a gender-responsive and public participatory planning approach. As part of 
the process, the city and provincial climate change action plans will be updated in coordination

then be applied to six additional secondary cities. Additional activities will develop technical

secondary cities; and training for environmental quality data collection and skills of enforcement 
officers. The output will also provide knowledge sharing events on applying environmental 
management planning, climate change resilient planning, and emissions and pollution inventories.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $14.1 million, of which $10.8 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the GEF14 and $2.0 million will be financed on a grant basis by the UCCRTF under the 
Urban Financing Partnership Facility.15 Key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. Ineligible 
expenditure items under the GEF and the UCCRTF will align with those for ADB-funded TA. The 
government will provide counterpart funds to finance tax and duties under the delegated TA 
Output 1, and provide counterpart support in the form of access to data and information, 
counterpart staffs, stakeholder coordination and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 72 months from January 2018 to December 
2023, while the TA Output 3 financed by UCCRTF will be completed in December 2021.16 The 
MONRE, as the executing agency for the TA, will closely coordinate with the implementing 
agencies as the project cities and provincial governments. ADB will administer the TA Outputs 2–
4. Administration of the TA Output 1 will be delegated to MONRE. The MONRE pollution control 
department will establish a project management unit (PMU) with adequate number of qualified 
staffs to administer the TA Output 1. For this output, the MONRE selects and signs the contract 
with the consultant, disbursement through advance payment facility. The results of the TA Output 
1 will be evaluated both separately and jointly with the other TA outputs for the overall TA outcome 
and outputs.

14.  Transfer of funds. The MONRE will open a project account in US dollar that will be 
maintained by PMU on behalf of the MONRE. The PMU will receive GEF fund transfers from ADB 
based on a quarterly disbursement plan agreed between MONRE and ADB. Payment will be 
based on review, acceptance and no objection from ADB of the PMU’s quarterly invoice.18  
 
15.  Cofinancier  requirements. The  UCCRTF  requires reporting  on  activities related  to

implementation tracking tools consistent with the GEF’s Guidelines on Monitoring and Evaluation.
